text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today 
i am doing a remake of an old classic green

papaya salad now this dish is so iconic of Thai 
cuisine that I think it's served at every single

tire restaurant outside of Thailand at least that 
I've ever been to now as a refresher green papaya

salad in Thai is called som tum now som is a 
term that either means orange or sour so sour in

this case and tom means two pound in a mortar 
and pestle and that is what we're gonna do today

so let's get started so what a lot of people don't 
know is that the word tom in Thailand refers to

a whole host of salads that are made in the mortar 
and pestle and there's hundreds and hundreds of

varieties and they don't have to contain any green 
papaya at all and the one we're going to make

today is called som tum Thai which means Thai 
style papaya salad which if you have a bias salad

offered at your local Thai restaurant I can almost 
guarantee it is this kind okay so let's first deal

with the papaya the green papaya is just an under 
ripe version of a regular papayas not any sort of

you know different variety and I'm going to peel 
it so we're going to julienne this papaya can do

that in one of two ways you can get an Asian style 
julienne peeler which is widely available these

days and just peel off strings or you can just 
use a knife you hold it sort of firmly in your

hand and you're going to chop chop chop okay and 
make lots of incisions watch your fingers please

and so once you've made lots of little incisions 
you're just gonna slice off a layer and then what

you get is beautiful little green papaya shreds 
make sure you make deep enough incisions and don't

slice off too thick because otherwise they just 
come out into one big sheet right now I'll show

you a little trick that will help these become 
even more crispy and crunchy so you're going to

soak this into some ice water and I don't know 
if back in high school you ever did that science

experiment where you stick a potato in water and 
suddenly they're like super-crunchy that's what's

happening here as well so in a lot of people 
do this in Thailand so it's not like I came up

with this so just let it soak for 10-15 minutes 
doesn't have to be long and I just do this as the

first thing then I get all my other stuff ready 
and then by the time I'm ready to go it would be

ah refreshed let's go over the ingredients real 
quick before we start pounding so I've got some

garlic and chilies chilies as much as you like 
people go crazy with papaya salad next we've got

some palm sugar now palm sugar in my last video 
I cooked it down into a syrup so that I wouldn't

have any trouble with it dissolving in the mortar 
and pestle this time around I figured out a way of

doing it without having to make a syrup you just 
have to make sure you cut it really really fine

first so what I do I shave it thinly with a sharp 
knife and then I run my knife over it again until

I don't have any more big chunks here I've got 
some dried shrimp really like shrimp jerky really

nice chewy meaty mommy flavor I've got big ones so 
I give them a rough chop but if you got small ones

you can leave them whole some roasted peanuts 
I roast mind fresh because I find the flavor is

better so you buy the peanuts raw and then I just 
put it in the oven some grape tomatoes that I cut

in half some long beans now these long beans are 
really really long you can also use French green

beans which are a little smaller nuttier but I 
would give those a quick blanch these you can

just eat raw seasoning now I've got fish sauce 
now if you are sort of you're still learning to

love fish sauce three craft brand is a good brand 
to start with because it is milder and smoother

than most other brands okay it's a little more 
expensive but I like to actually use it for salads

because it's not overpowering I've got some lime 
which I'm going to leave whole for now and then

some tamarind juice now I call it tamarind juice 
because that's kind of what it is but the jar will

often label it tamarind concentrate but it's 
not a concentrate it's a diluted tamarind pulp

so really very concentrate of the way any sense 
this one's called Terran paste concentrate which

really makes no sense but there you go this 
is optional you don't have to add tamarind if

you've got lime but I find that when you combine 
the two different Sidda t's the sort of sweeter

acidity of the tamron really helps round out the 
flavor really well but you can't find it you can

leave it out not a problem all right I'm going to 
drain the papaya it's now really perky and crisp

I can just feel that difference now I'm going 
to drain this you want to make sure you drain

it really really well because the last thing you 
want is all that liquid to dilute the flavor of

the dressing and then I pour it into a sort of 
a paper towel lined bowl so that it absorbs any

extra water that's hanging out usually at the 
bottom of the sieve so this mortar and pestle

is bigger and lighter it's made specifically for 
papaya salad now if you don't have one like this

don't worry in the written portion of the recipe 
I'll include instructions on how you could still

make the salad without any mortar and pestle at 
all okay so I'm going to go in first with garlic

and chilies you want to make sure the chilies and 
the garlic are pounded quite finely so you want to

add them first and try not to look at it because 
the chilies like to jump out and they could quite

easily get into your eye if you're not careful 
which I've learned the hard way wow that smells

spicy so next I'm going to add my palm sugar we 
need to make sure that it's all dissolved so I'm

using my mortar and pestle to really mash all that 
palm sugar and the moisture from the garlic and

the chilies will help that dissolve never turn it 
into sort of a muddy pasty consistency which will

then easily dissolve into the dressing after so 
next we're going in with the long beans and you

don't even have to chop these you can just break 
them directly into the mortar there we go now you

want to pound the long beans and actually get them 
to break a little bit because you want the beans

to be able to absorb the dressing because right 
now they're really firm and tight and if they're

intact the dressing is just going to sit around 
the outside it doesn't really get inside right

so you want to crush them until they're broken cut 
until they're mush just until they're broken okay

so just like that the dried shrimp and then I'm 
going to go in with just half my peanuts because

you're going to save the rest for later so pound 
that down I just want the peanuts to be kind of

broken up and I like that because they distribute 
better amongst the salad it helps thicken the

dressing a little bit this is sort of what it 
looks like it's sort of a yummy little mess

so now the rest of my dressing I've got the fish 
sauce going in some tamarin going in oh and that's

another thing different brands of tamarind even 
the same brand but different batches really vary

in acidity so it's one of those things you just 
kind of have to taste and adjust afterwards okay

okay so now my lime juice now I've got a little 
trick for you for the limes why I kept it whole

and the way Thai people cut limes we don't cut it 
in half like this we cut it first up a little bit

off center and this way this is really easy to 
squeeze okay because you don't have the core and

you've got a good grip on it and then the second 
piece you're trying to avoid the core so you come

off like that and then the last piece you cut the 
core off and these three piece will be easy to

squeeze squeeze the lime right into the mortar as 
much as you can and then I'm throwing in the skin

right in there because there's a lot of aromatic 
essential oils in the skin of the lime that when

you add to it it really adds a nice lime fresh 
flavors see once you learn how to cut your line

this way you'll never cut it any other way again 
okay now this one it's really big I'm just going

to cut the skin in half so it doesn't look like 
this massive piece of skin in the salad so now

I'm going to add another weapon and give this a 
stir and by the way you don't eat the skin okay

the skin is there just to add extra lime flavor 
to those resting you just eat around it just to be

clear oh this is where it starts to really smell 
like papaya salad all right last thing is going in

the papaya and tomatoes and now you kind of want a 
pound but lightly so I'm doing sort of the pounded

flip method so what I do is I flip so the dressing 
gets on top and then I just pounded a couple of

times lightly just to get the may doze a little 
bit Bruce and the juice of the tomatoes will come

out and mix a little bit become a part of the 
dressing but at this point you don't want to

be like pounding the heck out of it alright that's 
it let's plate it up woo oh that looks good oh yes

then you eat this with sticky rice and you just 
use the sticky rice to stop up all that sauce see

and then you see the lime then you know they use 
fresh lime because in Thailand a lot of sort of

cheap papaya event papaya salad vendors will use 
bottled lime juice which is mate it's like fake

lime juice basically and so when you don't see it 
then you kind of question whether they use real

lime juice or not I'm salivating Wow that is how 
a papaya salad should make you feel my mouth is a

little bit on fire because it's spicy but really 
refreshing it should make you feel alive like the

perky papaya stress crunchiness ok crunchiness is 
important so make sure you soak those paya shreds

in the ice water nutty peanuts also the long beans 
are nutty as well different kind of nutty so it's

just it's just so much fun I mean this is this 
is fun food so I hope you give this a try it's

such a classic and it's really really quite easy 
oh and by the way if you have a beer this goes

really well together so the recipe as always will 
be on hot Thai kitchen calm when you make it some

new photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram and 
please subscribe to the show if you haven't done

so and I will see you next time for your next 
delicious title Cheers now what a lot of people

don't know is that the Wood chop the wood lehigh 
bow so that far suddenly I have a Thai accent
